The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

Acceptance of Grant Funds – National Science Foundation
	 
Dr. Zhanjing (John) Yu, Engineering Professor, was appointed as a Program Director for the NSF Scholarships, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) Program, Division of Undergraduate Education at the National Science Foundation in Washington, D.C.  This is a temporary 12-month management position effective January 18, 2011 through January 17, 2012. During this assignment, Dr. Yu remains an employee of the District with his salary and benefits paid by the NSF grant funds.  
	 
The appointment of Dr. Yu as a “rotating” Program Director with NSF provides the following benefits:  
Raises the profile of our college and enhances its reputation
Provides networking opportunities with other NSF programs and other Federal agencies and organizations
Provides knowledge and insight into the latest developments in undergraduate education from a national perspective that will keep our curricula and pedagogue up to date
Provides experience in the management, operation and evaluation of programs within STEM

items.item_details:
Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee.    Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties and the District anticipates regular bi-monthly meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee is required to have a minimum of seven (7) members representing the following groups:
	 
- One (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government
	 
- One (1) business community located in the District
	 
- One (1) senior citizens’ organization
	 
- One (1) bona-fide taxpayers’ association
	 
- One (1) support organization for the District, such as SJECCD Foundation
	 
- Two (2) community at-large
	 
The District has strived to maintain the seven-person committee as structured above.  It has been determined that the committee’s function would benefit by expanding that number in the categories where there are additional qualified applicants.  This will also assist in the ability for a quorum to be reached at the regularly scheduled meetings.
	 
Staff will continue to seek candidates to fill one of the required categories; a representative of a support organization for the District. Listed below is a list of individuals recommended for appointment to the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Oversight Committee commencing March 9, 2011. The Board of Trustees will be provided with a follow-up recommendation when additional candidate(s) are identified.
	       
Representing                 Appointee                Term Expires    
Small Business                    Bob Nunez                      March 8, 2013
Taxpayer Association         Douglas McNea              March 8, 2013

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  This is a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and carries the requirement of a citizens’ bond oversight committee.
	 
A resolution was passed by the Board of Trustees at the December 14, 2010 meeting that amended and restated bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010. 
	 
Included in Section 9 of the bylaws is the following:
	 
Officers.  The Board, upon the recommendation of the Chancellor, shall appoint the initial Chair of the Committee.  Thereafter the Committee shall elect the Chair and a Vice-Chair who shall act as Chair only when the Chair is absent.  No person shall serve as chair for more than two consecutive years. 
	 
The Chancellor recommends the appointment of Ms. Kathy Kyne as chairperson of the new committee to serve an initial term commencing March 9, 2011.  Ms. Kyne, representing a senior citizens’ organization, is still in her first term on the committee and is the only remaining member from the Measure G - 2004 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
		 
December 14, 2010 - The Board of Trustees was presented with Fiscal Year 2010-2011 First Quarter Report. A significant point identified for the Board of Trustees is the structural imbalance of the District’s expenses exceeding its revenue by $4.8 million.
January 10, 2011- Governor Brown presented his budget proposal where he identified a $400 million reduction to the Community College System which translates to approximately a $3.3 million reduction for San Jose Evergreen-Community College District.
February 12, 2011 - The Board of Trustees based on best case scenario unanimously adopted the principles and assumptions of a negotiated salary reduction of 3.5% and benefit cost reduction of $1 million to achieve the necessary budget savings. As a safeguard measure, the Board directed staff to return with the necessary reduction in force to ensure that the District reduces its expenditures by $3.3 million effective June 30, 2011 if negotiations with employee groups fail to secure the necessary concessions.
		 
Identified are (1) positions to eliminate, (2) employees who are to be laid off, and (3) employees who may be bumped due to the exercising of seniority
		 
		 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 030811-2, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.

Background and Analysis: 
At the July 22nd, 2009 Board of Trustees meeting, the Board approved the Greater South Bay Green Jobs Corps Program grant (R975686) that was awarded to Workforce Institute. This grant was funded at $937,873 and runs from June 1, 2009 until March 31, 2011. The purpose of this grant was to train at-risk youth for employment in the emerging green career fields. 
	 
This program was focused on serving the most high-risk youth that were 18-24 years of age with multiple barriers to employment.  This program also funded a full-time Vocational Employment Specialist to serve the participants throughout the duration of the grant. This position was posted as a categorically funded position that ended on March 31, 2011. 
	 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 030811-3, Eliminate Positions and Layoff Classified Employees; and authorize District representatives to provide the affected employee with forty-five (45) day notices of layoff.

Background
On January 25, 2010 the Board appointed Trustees Mayra Cruz, Jeffrey Lease and Randy Okamura to serve as the Board’s self evaluation committee.  The committee was charged to work with the Chancellor to develop and recommend a process and criteria for the evaluation of the Board by March 8, 2010.  This item complies with the charge to the committee.  The information detailed below describes the methodology and survey instrument to be used, the targeted focus of the evaluation, the proposed cohort to be surveyed, the timeline for completion and scheduled report back in public session for discussion of the findings.
	 
The committee met on February 24 and  began with a discussion of existing Board Policy on Self Evaluation (BP 2745), past outcomes and evaluation processes and current concerns and areas of focus including; governance, financial solvency and recent “shared recommendations” included in the Accreditation Commission findings for both colleges. Based on this discussion the committee agreed to focus the self evaluation in two areas:  (1) Board Operations/Effectiveness (2) Accreditation Findings.
	 
Methodology
The committee reviewed a draft survey instrument derived from a list of validated questions developed for Trustee use by the Community College League for California (see attached).  All items in the survey have been tested and validated.  In addition, the survey is constructed to permit analysis at two levels (1) Governance and, (2) Compliance with Accreditation Standards.
	 
Expanded Cohort
By definition, the process of self evaluation by Community College Board of Trustees is just that—evaluation of performance conducted by board members about themselves. It is not required that others evaluate the board.  Nevertheless, the committee recommends the participation of an expanded list of participants to be included in the evaluation of the board as follows:
	 
	 
Internal
External*
Board Members
District’s Executive Team
District’s Shared Governance Council
College Shared Governance Councils
Labor Representatives ( FA, CSEA, MSC)
Student Leadership Groups (EVC and SJCC Associated Student Government)
					 
City Council
City Managers
San Jose Unified School District Superintendent
Milpitas Unified School District Superintendent
Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools
Mayors ( San Jose/Milpitas)
Legislative Representatives
Congressional Representatives
					 
					 
*A different and abbreviated version of the survey instrument will be used with external constituents.  
					 
	 
	 
  
Timeline
Because of the expanded nature of the proposed survey process the committee recommends to extend the timeline for completion from March 22 to May 10.  The findings of the survey will be discussed in public session.  It is expected that this discussion will generate specific guidelines for the development of measurable outcomes designed to address those Board performance areas that need to be strengthened.
	 
Summary
It has been two years since the Board completed a self evaluation.  The proposed methodology and expanded inclusion of internal and external participants is designed to provide a more constructive, comprehensive and honest review of the board.  It is a courageous step that while not required by law or policy, has as its aim the board’s willingness to ask their constituents, internal and external, for their honest opinion in attempt to move forward in a transparent and responsive manner.  It is also the intent of the board to ensure a direct and targeted response to each of the “shared recommendations” included in the Accreditation Reports to ensure that those findings citing board performance are directly addressed.
